items.description: Beverley Brook area in Merton, Sutton, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames and Wandsworth
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.message:
Heavy rain and thunderstorms, bringing the potential for locally intense rainfall, are forecast to affect the London area today, Monday 26th July. While uncertainty remains around exact timings and which areas will experience the heaviest rain, the risk of heavy showers is highest between 10am and 7pm today. The rain is not expected to be as intense as yesterday, Sunday 25th July. Where showers fall there is a possibility that rivers could respond quickly and overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible. Surface water flooding may also affect low lying areas. 

We recommend you monitor local weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We are monitoring the situation closely and have staff out on the ground checking and clearing trash screens. We will update this message by 9pm tonight, Monday 26th July, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar remains very high, but at Alverstone, it is now slowly falling.  At Sandown the river continues to rise and is not expected to peak until at least 19:30 this evening (26/07/21). Over the next 24 hours, water levels will remain very high and flooding of gardens, access and cycle tracks will continue. Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will experience minor impact flooding. Ditches at Fort Holiday Park may also struggle to drain. Today (Monday 26/07/21) and for the rest of this week, the risk of further fast moving, heavy and scattered showers continues. The river will be incredibly sensitive to any further rainfall and we are monitoring the situation closely. Even though the river should continue lowering for the rest of this afternoon and early evening, we would like residents to remain prepared for further potential flood impacts this week. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Tuesday 27/07/21 or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force for Monday eveningâ€™s tide due to now stronger winds than previously forecast. The forecast high water is 21:30 on 26/07/2021 with a level of 6.14 mAOD and a Force 4 westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. Local flood impacts are possible this evening, and conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. High tide levels will reduce in the coming days, however moderate Force 4 to Force 6 winds are forecast this week. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further updates are issued. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by midday on Tuesday 27/07/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Beverley Brook at Worcester Park
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Merton, Surrey, Sutton

items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  There is no longer a threat of flooding to properties, though standing water and debris may still remain in gardens and low lying areas near the Beverley Brook.  Further thunderstorms and heavy rain are forecast over the next 12 hours but these are not expected to be as intense as yesterday, Sunday 25th July. 

We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing debris from trash screens. There is still a flood alert in force for the Beverley Brook which means there is a risk of flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river as a result of forecast heavy rain today, Monday 26th July 2021. 

Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and take photographs of any flood damage.

items.description: St Johns, Ryde
items.message: At St Johns, water levels in the Monktonmead continue to fall. In addition to impacts at St Johns Train Station, exceptionally intense showers caused widespread surface impacts in Ryde and Binstead yesterday (25/07/2021). In total, over 60mm was recorded at Ryde rain gauge over 8 hours. 40mm of that rainfall fell in just 1 hour between 16:00 and 17:00. Today (Monday 26/07/2021) it is possible that some heavy showers could affect the Isle of Wight, although confidence is very low. If further heavy rain does affect the river today, then we may have to issue further advice.

items.description: The Stour Brook from Haverhill to Sturmer
items.message: River levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is unsettled for the next few days with scattered thunderstorms. We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue alert messages as required. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Upper River Wey

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar remains very high, but it is now slowly falling. In Langbridge, Horringford and Alverstone, out of bank flooding affecting gardens, roads, access tracks and cycle paths is expected to continue over the next 18 hours. A Flood Alert will remain in force and will be updated regularly to cover these impacts. Today (Monday 26/07/21) and for the rest of this week, there is the potential for further heavy showers to develop. The river will remain incredibly sensitive to further rainfall, so should any heavy rain affect the area (especially over the next 12 hours) then we may need to issue further advice and messages.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Hampstead Lock at Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high following intense, localised rainfall on Sunday 25 July 2021.  High river levels will remain from Bethersden to Staplehurst throughout tonight Monday 26 July. Further storms are forecast in Kent from 4am tomorrow 27/07/2021, but there is low confidence on the precise location given the unpredictable nature of thunderstorms. If further rainfall occurs over the Beult catchment, river levels are likely to increase further and flooding of low lying land and roads will be possible, particularly around Bethersden, Pluckley, Smarden and Headcorn. The forecast is for heavy, localised rainfall to continue this week. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Tuesday 27/02/22021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are falling at the Stapleford river gauge. Flooding of low lying roads and farmland is still possible during this evening, Monday 26 July. We expect flooding to affect the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. River levels will continue to fall overnight. There is no significant rainfall forecast, however isolated heavy showers are possible. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Tuesday 27 July, or as the situation changes.
